section.heading: Argument of William B. Moore, Jr.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 90, Johnny Ray Smith, Petitioner, versus United States of America.
Mr. Moore, you may proceed.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, Honorable Associate Justices, if it please the Court.
This is a criminal case which has been in the federal courts throughout its entire life.
In November 1949, Johnny Ray Smith was apprehended under the Osceola Hotel in Geneva, Alabama by the FBI.
He and two others, who later became his codefendants, were carried to Dothan where they were arraigned and incarcerated.
They -- this was on a Friday.
They were questioned that night in Saturday and Sunday, and right in the early Monday morning, the 21st day of November, 1949, they were carried to Montgomery.
There, they had a conference with the Assistant United States Attorney.

And during that time or some time during the morning while they were in the United States Attorney's Office, FBI agent John Lill went to the chambers of Judge Charles Kennamer, presiding judge, and had a conference with him about this matter.
Shortly thereafter, Judge Kennamer went on the bench, Johnny Ray Smith and his two defendants -- codefendants, who were two 17-year-old boys, Johnny Ray was 26, went into the courtroom.
And in the words of the Fifth Circuit after a few didactic questions, all three defendants pled guilty.

Whereupon, the judge says, “I have discussed this matter with Mr. Lill,” meaning the FBI agent and immediately proceeded to pronounce sentences, 30 years to Johnny Ray and 15 years to each of the two 17-year-old boys.
Now, Smith was incarcerated in the federal prison system and finally was sent to California to Alcatraz.
He there initiated a petition, a -- a petition for writ of habeas corpus, and it got to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals there.
They told him he had the wrong remedy, that he should be proceeding under 2255.
Thereupon, he filed in the Fifth Circuit in Alabama after making due motions to Judge Kennamer.
The Fifth Circuit of Alabama of the Fifth -- not of Alabama but the United States Court of Appeals Circuit, granted him this relief under 2255 and ordered a hearing.
At that stage, I was fortunate enough to be appointed by the Court to come in to defend the man's rights.

We had a full hearing with the petitioner being brought from Alcatraz and then the presiding District Judge decided we were entitled to no relief so we went to the -- back to the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals.
And in 238 F. 2d 925, they issued another opinion.
We thought we had won our lawsuit at that point.
They decided that when it comes to the controlling question whether or not the waivers and the plea was taken in violation of due process, that it was.
And in the opinion they set out a number of reasons why they thought it was.
Then the judgment is reversed, the cause is remanded with directions to grant the motion to set aside the conviction and sentence and to proceed further and not inconsistently, herewith.
The United States Attorney saw fit to file for rehearing.

The rehearing was refused but the Court added a further sentence in addition to what I just read, including if the District Judge is of the opinion that the ends of justice required it, permitting the defendant to withdraw his waiver of counsel and his plea of guilty, and to stand trial.

We went back to the Fifth Circuit Court again -- to the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals again, and pointed out that we thought it was quite inconsistent in the body of the opinion to say, the due -- due process has not been granted because of the waivers and these other matters which I'm going to bring up that we thought we were entitled to more relief but we didn't get it.
Hence, we are here.
Now, what our District did -- Judge did, when the case was sent back to him with these instructions, was the following.
When the case was called we appeared and he did remove -- he followed the Court in removing the conviction and the sentence.
As the man stood before the Court, with the conviction and sentence removed, we asked for a writ of habeas corpus, which was refused.
We then asked to withdraw our plea of guilty, which was refused.
Then we asked to withdraw the waivers of indictment of counsel and venue which was refused.
Then as he stood before the Court, based on this plea he had made in 1949, the Court sentenced him to 10 additional years.
The man had been in jail eight years at that time.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is that the same judge?

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: No, sir.
Judge Frank Johnson was appointed and this is his first case that he had heard since he went on the bench.
And he had heard the entire 2255.
When it came back to him, he reduced the sentence on the fact we had a 30-year sentence to start with.
The man had served eight years.
The judge took cognizance of eight years and resentenced the man to an additional 10 years from that date, which he is serving at this time.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Why -- may I ask, following up the question of my Brother Black.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Why didn't the -- the matter go to the sentence -- original sentencing judge?

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: He did.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Oh, that's a good answer.
I didn't realize it.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Judge Kennamer passed on --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I see.
That's right.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: -- and Judge Frank Johnson was appointed.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If you win, what do you get?
What happens?
What -- what is the contention between you, you just get a new trial, is that all you're asking for?

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: No, sir.
I'm -- I'm going to get into that right now.
There's -- that there's a --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you claim that you're entitled to be turned -- he's entitled to be turned loose or he's entitled to withdraw his plea of guilt and have a new trial?
Which do you claim?

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Well I claim some other things other than that if it please the Court and which I want to get to right now if I may.
And I -- I want quite fully.
In the first place, I say that this Court, under the proceeding that they had, did not have jurisdiction.
The reasons to these.
This case is a kidnapping case and it's -- it's a federal law.
It's the Lindbergh Law, Section 1201.
And under that case the man is accused of a capital crime.
Now --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Well, he is accused, if it please the Court, whether or not it proved or not, it's unless.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: No, sir.
I do not.
Under the Parrino case if it does not specify whether the man did or did not release the victim unharmed, he can be found guilty of a capital crime.
(Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Are you saying, Mr. Moore that if the indictment itself alleges that in fact the victim was unharmed, there could by no possibility be a capital sentence?

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But if it doesn't say so, there may be a capital sentence although the victim in fact was unharmed.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That's a jury question of a fact where he was or was not released unharmed.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well I mean if -- if in fact the indictment, there may be a prosecution for and a conviction of the Lindbergh offense and the imposition of a death sentence, although the indictment says nothing about what happened to the victim.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, that's what the Parrino case holds --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: -- exactly.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And therefore -- but if the indictment itself qualifies it by saying that the victim was unharmed, then there couldn't be a capital sentence.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: That is exactly our contention, sir.
Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So I gather from the fact here, an information that was not an indictment, that's the point upon which you rest your challenge to jurisdiction that this should have --

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- been an --

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: And I'm -- and I'm going to tell you --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: He should have been indicted.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: -- why, if I may.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That is your point, isn't it?

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.
It -- it was an affirmation in this case and I say that the United States Attorney has no authority by which he can bring in information.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Because it's a capital offense.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Because it's a capital offense and the only --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you prove it -- but you prove it because of what you and I went through of what happens if an indictment is brought.
If an indictment is brought which merely says there was a kidnapping, period.
He may be sentenced to death on a showing that in fact the victim was hurt.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: That's right, I know.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: No, sir.
And the rule -- Rule 7 (b) of the Federal Criminal Rules, only allows an information where the offense is not capital.
I hadn't answered your question yet, and I realized it.
But as the first step in this, in -- in our contention, it -- if this is in fact a capital case, then there is no way by which the United States Attorney can start this by an information.
And I -- I've got to convince you of that first, at least I mean I've got to make that point.

That this is a capital case or can be a capital case, because by the very nature of things the man can be found guilty -- is this what he's charged with, doesn't necessarily mean that's what he did, even though it was by an information.
Then the judge can ask for a jury, and the jury can find that the victim was not released unharmed.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, that's --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I suppose, Mr. Moore, it would be analogous -- somewhat analogous would it not to situation where a man is -- is charged with murder but was by an information under which, of course, he could be executed.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But as a matter of fact he was -- he was convicted of second degree murder.
Your position would be of course that -- that the information would be invalid because he might have been convicted of first degree murder instead of second degree murder.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: I doubt, of course, if it please the Court.
He might have even been home in bed --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: -- and not --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) and -- and then --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: -- complete the answer.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, are -- are you saying in effect that you can't prove that the information that you can't establish that the charge may be made by information, by -- or the fact that an information was filed?

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: No, sir.
Any information is just like the indictment.
It's got --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I mean you can't -- that's the Rule 7 says, "An offense which may be punished by death shall be prosecuted by indictment."

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So the question is, what is the nature of the -- of the offense that's charged, not until you prove it's an allowable information prosecution because you brought and information?

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That would be begging the whole question.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: There's -- there's no dispute in this case if you haven't -- whatever the validity of your position is --

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- under no circumstances no matter what this indictment is charged could this man have been sentenced to death, thus the victim was unharmed.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: If it please the Court --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Is that right?

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: If it please the Court, I contest that violently in that that this man has never been tried.
Under the Parker case you could take evidence to see what sort of punishment he's going to get --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: -- but --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But there's no dispute here that this man -- this victim of the kidnapping was released unharmed, is there?

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: It never -- I don't think it --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Is there any dispute?

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: -- could ever come before the Court to be determined properly.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I'm just asking you what the fact is.
Is there any dispute on that fact?

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: There were no physical marks on the man.
Whether he received --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: And therefore --

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: -- a mental trauma, I --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- the fact --

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: -- don't know.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- the actual facts are that no matter what this indictment has alleged or the information it alleged, this man could not have been given a capital sentence.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Unless the jury had disagreed with the findings in this case and thought that his -- by being frightened he was harmed and had seen fit to recommend the death penalty, which is entirely within the realm of possibility if it please the Court.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The only -- the only evidence as to injury is that there was an absence of any signs of physical injury, is that it?
But the way you suggest of then other kinds of injury at least the jury could have so found that it's gone to trial.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: If it please the Court, yes, sir.
On this 2255, I raised a point on Page 66 of the transcript that we should not have gone into the evidence of the kidnapping in this 2255 it -- it was not proper at that time.
We have taken evidence, so to speak, which should have been presented in the trial, and if we'd had a trial we'd try the case a different way.
So --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In your short answer to Justice -- is it your -- doesn't your position require you to say, or make it appropriate for you to say, in answer to the question of Brother Harlan that what the facts are, are immaterial.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The question is what kind of an offense --

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: What is he charged for?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- if protection --

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- is charged?

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, that's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I suppose you could also say that unless --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well that's the -- that's the -- the issue.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I suppose you could also say that in -- in the posture of this case you're not even chargeable with notice of what the prosecution might have -- might have attempted to prove against you.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: No, sir.
I don't think we have to.
That's right, if you start relying on what the attorney is going to charge your client with the opposing attorney well you– certainly weaken your position.
That's one issue in -- this -- that's the first issue in this case.
The second issue --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well if you prevail in that issue that's the end of your appeal.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, and the Judge Rives, in the lower court in the minority opinion adopted that position all the way through.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What do you say to the suggestion of Justice Harlan by which he replied that that's the issue?
Whether you determine or whether the question of filing a charge by information rather than requiring an indictment to say that that is the requirement of the rule is the very issue.
What do you say to that?
That it begs the question to say that you're limited to the potential charge and not what the fact in a particular record as that.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: I don't think that you have to try your lawsuit to -- to see what your choice is with and that's what it makes us do.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well in this case the sentencing judge, Judge Kennemar --

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: He was the original sentencing judge, Judge Kennemar.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Oh, I beg your pardon.
Judge Johnson.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: There's no question in the record that he was (Voice Overlap) that a capital sentence could not be imposed here.
He said the maximum sentence and you realize (Voice Overlap) is it not?

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: So that really the nub of the situation between you and the Government is, whether this requirement of Rule 7 is to be judged in terms of the actual facts in a particular case as to whether a death sentence could have been given, or in terms, as you claim, as to what the or what the information charges.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: And your position --

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: That's that's what --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- would have to be, I take it, that in any situation where there was no dispute, no dispute whatever, that a death sentence could not be imposed still, the District Attorney if he wants to proceed by information in order to get a waiver of the indictment has got to allege in the indictment -- in the information as the man was unharmed.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: That's right.
That's the position and that's point number one.

Point number two, if I may go into it, sir is the fact that an FBI agent acting in line and scope of his duty as an FBI agent and in no other capacity, and of the chambers of the judge who was later the sentencing judge, and the record will reveal that he had a good bit to say about -- about this man, about his alleged confession, about this crime, about other crimes, information he got from another FBI agent, and a rather full report.
Now, the record would also show that Mr. Lill went to California when the habeas corpus was held and had a good bit to say at that time about this and gave testimony our there.

At that time there was some talk about a presentence report and the Government has made quite a point out of the fact that what difference does it make if this information was given before instead of after.
Our answer to that is this.
Mr. Lill was never giving information in the form of a presentence report.
Mr. Lill admitted, off on my examination in Montgomery that we had a probation service there.
He knew the probation officers by name.
We didn't have to -- the Court didn't have to go to an FBI agent to -- to get a presentence report.
Mr. Lill never left his job as an FBI agent as this Court held in Von Moltke case.
It's laudable for a -- a government agent to be a government agent but at the same time, he can't work for both sides of the street.

Williams case was brought out this morning and there a probation officer and the probation report is certainly supposed to be giving the full truth, picture and possibly be the man's protector if, possible.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Moore, haven't you already run -- won in that aspect of the case in the Court of Appeals?
They -- they agreed with you.
They said that this procedure impacted the validity of the sentence imposed by the deceased judge.

turn.speaker: william_b_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. William B. Moore, Jr.
turn.text: It was --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Well sir, I -- I must repeat again the two of possible three-string argument and I don't mean to be unnecessarily persistent about this.
And, that is, that I am not in a position to say that Judge Hand was right or wrong about the necessity for alleging.
But if he is right, then he and indeed the judge in the Parker case said that one could determine whether the victim was released unharmed from circumstances outside the specific pleading.
And that's what --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And that statute is -- just reading your statute, I'm inclined to find the convicting proof leading to that conclusion.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: If that is right sir, then I submit that in this case there is unquestioned and undoubted evidence or undisputed evidence.
The fact was the fact.

If I need go further and I do not want to be driven to -- to go further, but I present this because I think that a full discussion of what is perhaps a matter of first instance, in this Court, ought to be developed.
If I need go further then I would take the position that I have outlined as the second string to my bow and would cite in support of that.
This Court's decision in the Cordell case where in a footnote, the Court says that in effect, you may proceed for the lesser of the two aspects of the offense by information.

Unless I convey the impression that that was not a thought -- a well thought-out part of the Cordell case, I hasten to add that it was thoroughly briefed by both sides that was appealed from that case.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- very low to go beyond the necessities of the case usually but it strikes me as it'd be highly undesirable to have this case go off just on the facts in this case and leave up in the air whether informations may be filed in these cases.
So, there's a general question presented here.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: That's perfectly true, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (A) -- (a) is it necessary to be charged and if it's included in his deed that it was not necessary to be charged, then is the offense, that which kidnapping with all the possible consequences and therefore not is a measure of punishment and not part of the offense.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Well if you all please -- if as I believe your -- your remarks suggest, the Court may become interested in the broader problem here presented.
I would ask the Court to consider the material at the end of our brief which I think rather, persuasively, talks about the policy considerations with respect to the waiver of the indictment.

And I need not belabor you the point except to say that it would be a most serious decision from the point of view of those prisoners who may have to languish in jail for months awaiting the action of a grand jury which does not meet as frequently as it does in our larger Metropolitan areas.

Waiting only for the formality of an indictment when he knows, and I must assume for these purposes, that he is guilty of the crime, and wants to plead to the crime having released the man unharmed he --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But where is the hardship there really?It's just a difference of whether he's languishing in jail or languishing in prison isn't it?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Well, the -- the hardship here, Mr. Justice Stewart, but a man gets no credit for time in the federal system, prior to his sentence.

And so every moment that he spends in jail prior to the judge giving him a term of his is, is granted and sir, I may suggest and if I may be permitted at least from my personal experience in the United States Attorney's Office, I -- I -- it has happened so very often that a man apprehended in the course of a crime, comes in and says, “Now, look, let's -- let's get this show on the road.
I'm -- I'm -- you -- you got me."
Now, how can I most quickly get this -- start to do the time that I'm going to get?
And there's no nonsense about the fact that the man knows that he's going to get time.
If in -- if in New York, that happened, I -- I suggest there's a grand jury in session, at least everyday, and indeed many grand juries who are in session concurrently.
But if you go to the more rural areas of our country, it maybe months and --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: -- the notes of the --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- districts where the grand jury meets maybe twice a year.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Exactly sir and that was pointed out as the reason for rule set that.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is right now.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: -- is permitting the waiver.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That now as the Rule 7 also expressed that considered public policy that in cases where the punishment might be execution, that this inconvenience and this hardship of being in jail as long as five or six months is countered -- more than counter-balanced by the importance and necessity of having a man charged with an offense as serious as that only by action of the -- of the grand jury and -- almost weighing the -- the gravity of the eventual punishment against the -- a few months in jail as a -- as a de minimis situation in that kind of an offense.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Mr. Justice, having formulated the proposition in those terms, I can't but agree but I believe that you would perhaps assume the -- the conclusion in the formulation.
The question here is if it's a capital offense and I am positing my argument on the assumption that the victim was released unharmed.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you please?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: As far as the policy is concerned, do you think anything in your argument that would make it wrong for the Government to have the information of this (Inaudible) to say that the -- the victim was released unharmed and with the Government be bound by that if it said it that's how he'd be guilty and guilty too if that's what was said.
If --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) why wouldn't that be a better way of preserving the rights of the party that you're talking on the present policy?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I would say that the necessity for letting -- for -- for alleging the lesser of the two possible aspects of the crime is at least to my untutored ear not a -- the -- the best way to approach the problem of the giving of -- telling a man what it is he is charged with.
I think it's much more direct to do it --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: -- in terms of, you are charged with the greater crime.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In my untutored mind, I can think of nothing better than charging a man in information with that but he's charged with namely kidnapping somebody and turned him loose without harming him --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- unless the law some -- unless there's something in the law to make such surpluses to such an extent that the Government wouldn't be bound by the limitations of its charge in the information.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I would suggest that if -- I -- I can only go back again to the Parrino case with Judge Hand speaking for the Second Circuit.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I've just read it.
It's there?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: It is indeed, sir.

And I would ask this Court to note that although Judge Hand uses very broad language about the necessity for making an allegation of all of the aspects of the offense and he finds that this is not an aspect of the offense, but he is using this language in a case which is very peculiar because it is a statute of limitations case and as I read it, and perhaps I am reading it with more intuition than understanding but as I read it, I have the feeling that what Judge Hand was there saying that it isn't good enough for the prosecutor to charge that the man was released harmed to convert it into a capital case because that gives the prosecutor free play.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Wouldn't it be enough on the other way (Inaudible) to allege that he was released unharmed to -- to his defense?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Well, --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Or would --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: logically, what I would say that if he -- if it were alleged that the victim was released unharmed under those circumstances, I am not convinced that it would be simple variance for example, to put in evidence of the fact that the man was released harmed --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But why do you say that --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I do think that you would be bound by -- I'm sorry sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do you say you would not be bound by it?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I -- I think you -- I think the Government probably would, which is to -- to make the allegation, that is I think we are bound to a point where in the -- the real question seems to be what is the best procedure --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: --for --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If the Government would be bound by -- and what -- what is the countervailing consideration of putting it into information as Justice Black suggests, what -- what burden or inconvenience does that cast if I'm the pleader?
And if it is, if he be harmed -- bound by it, then we -- we --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- we already began.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: No, sir.

I think that probably he would be bound by it and I must, of course, say that if I were the Assistant United States Attorney and the United States Attorney drawing up an information or an indictment as the case may be, it would not be terribly difficult to put these words into --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, put yourself in the situation of a U.S. Attorney, who doesn't seem like you do.
What kind of feelings would prompt the U.S. Attorney to fix about it, not putting it in?
What embarrassment to make that as a necessary consequence of a decision that if you don't put it in, then there's the potentiality of a capital offense?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Then I would go -- I -- I would have to take your argument, sir, and take it one step forward.
And that is, the poor fellow who may be caught and says, I want out.
I want to start to do my time.
And the United States Attorney under those circumstances, well, I suppose there he could charge him with an information.
I'm sorry if I missed -- I -- I misdirected my remarks to you.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: He could, sir.
But I really think that the problem is one, of where a man has been released harmed.
It seems to me that that is the allegation that perhaps ought to be made to put the man who is now being charged, on notice of the fact that this is a -- this is the capital offense.
The harming of a man during a kidnapping, that is the thing that leads to the capital offense.
And I say I find support for this position in the cases that I have read and I -- I have found no support for the alternative position.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So that would be another fact to the method of needing here, I guess I should say --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I would say, yes.
That that the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If he didn't allege -- have the allegation he's harmed.
No, but it wasn't capital and if it did say he were harmed say it was a capital.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: That's right.
It's just as practical one way --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Or you --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: -- or the other.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Or you can get it the other way.
And when you value information --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- but it's not charged, it's not there.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Well, sir, the -- the [Laughs] --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It is.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: -- my second argument is that the Government should and I should say that I have asked that the records of the department be searched because I thought this would be of some interest to the Court.
And I find that, at least from the research, that we have done, we have never proceeded against a kidnapper who has released his victim harmed except by making the allegation that he wants --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In other words --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: -- to be --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: -- harmed.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The only case.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Now, I -- I am facing to qualify, Justice --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: -- Black, but my research which I personally didn't adapt to but which I asked to be done and I asked that it be done several days ago during the preparation of this argument.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, there's one that the --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: -- that the answer came back that in all of the cases and those people who'd been in the department for donkey's years in this section of the department that we seek the capital offense only after an allegation that the victim has been released harmed.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But isn't that a practical or does one have -- does one go on with his imagination?

I know nothing about the records in this cases but it seems to be not too imaginative to assume that there are kidnapping cases in which an indictment for one reason or another but partly for the reason that you give is sought to be secured very promptly.
And the state of the victim is not yet determined at the time that the indictment is brought.
He may have been slightly bruised.
It may turn out to be one of the mysterious things, that later, results in death or so that -- and that is left open and I take it to statute.
And I take it.
I can argue.
I can read the statute as dealing with that probability that you wait until the end to find out what kind of punishment should be imposed --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Which is the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- because the fate of the victim may not be unambiguous at the time of the prosecution.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: In which case, sir, I -- I would suggest that if one may wait to the end of the -- of the proceedings before one makes a determination, then in this case, there can be no question that the victim was released unharmed --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: -- and that therefore this is not --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Oh, no --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: -- a capital offense.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Silverman --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But then the purpose of my -- my remark is [laughs]

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Silverman, suppose this information had been filed after the time limit for the filing of -- of an information of indictment in a normal felony case, not a capital case, would the statute of limitations be open to the defendant in this case?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I would say -- if you say in a felony, in -- in a normal felony case.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Probably a felony case.
Yes, that was -- well, just an ordinary felony case.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: And the indictment here in that --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Had this information had been filed beyond that time limit?
Would the statute limitations be -- the defense be open to the man in this case with this kind of an information?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I would say it would be open to in that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You'd say it would be open, right.
Why?
Because under no circumstances --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Would this then be --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- could be, because under no circumstances, could he be convicted of a capital offense.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: That's right, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, I didn't understand to say before that -- that you thought under no circumstances could he have been convicted of a capital offense under this kind of an information.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: That was, if I may go back to my former -- my -- my prior formulation, that was the second string.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: See my trouble -- my trouble is that it seems to me you both -- you both embrace at the same time reject the language of -- of Judge Hand when he said this Court within petitioner's brief, we agree that the indictment stated all the essentials of the crime as charged, and that it was not necessary to allege that the victim was not released unharmed in order that the jury might recommend the death penalty.
We, too, think that the indictment need not allege whether the victim had been released unharmed.
So --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: My -- my -- you're absolutely right, sir that my opponent and I point to the same case and -- and indeed almost the language and draw different conclusions from it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: If I go through that, however --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well I -- I wish you would if could in a -- in few words, tell me how you construe this language to -- to support this information.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: If it is not a necessary element of the offense to allege whether a victim has been released harmed or unharmed, and I must then seek refuge in the -- in -- in the other thing that Judge Hand says.

And if you may look to the entire proceedings to make that determination, then I say, in this case if it was not necessary to make the allegation and if we do look to the other -- to the remaining part of this proceeding, we come to the undeniable conclusion that the victim was released unharmed.
Therefore I say that if Judge Hand was right, then this is not a capital offense.
Now, I -- I -- so this is obviously an inability on my part to communicate the thought that I'm trying to express but I'm not sure that I --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Therefore --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: -- can differ with that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But it was -- if the least language is, that the information did not say that he was unharmed.
And Judge Hand said that regardless of the fact that it did not say that he was unharmed, the jury had the right to find him guilty of a capital offense.
Am I wrong in that?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: If the remaining evidence showed that in --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: No --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: -- fact he was released --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Would that --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: -- harmed.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But that is within this language.

Now if he -- because he goes on to say, “We too think that the indictment need not allege whether the victim had been released unharmed,” now it may be there are other language in there and if you say that there's language that qualifies this, I won't trouble you to read it because I'll read it myself.
But I would talk to you about this language that was quoted in the petitioner's brief.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: And I will go further and ask Your Honor to again to -- to read the Parker case which is hand in hand with Parrino.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, but I was trying to -- I was trying to confine it to Parrino for the moment.
Maybe we get to this point.
But if you say there's other language in there that qualifies that out, I'll --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I'll get it for you.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Yes sir, I'm -- I'm --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I'm certain that you will find in the Parrino case.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, don't take your time.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: All right, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I don't know if I'll be taking to your time but I would like to ask you this question to get my -- your view on this.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: As I understand that your first position is that this should be left open for it to be determined by one might say extrinsic evidence extrinsic.
It doesn't have to appear in the indictment or information.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Must -- it -- it's left up in the air.
Then you have two other elements as I see it.
One of them is that the indictment should always charge it on the information so you'd know.
The other one is that an information should charge that the -- it's in an information that should charge if it's not -- if he was not harmed, when he was released.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: From the practical standpoint of the Government, if we are going to have to adopt one of those rules, and one didn't want to take your first rule, your first proposal.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Which are the other two?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: The other two are, if there is an allegation that is necessary, it must come in terms of the aggravated circumstances of the crime that absent the aggravated circumstances charged.
One may go only -- that one must assume that, on capital nature of it.
If you want to make it a capital crime, you must charge in undeniable language that the man was released harmed.
That would --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: -- be the second string to the bow.
And the third string is the one that Mr. Justice Stewart referred to and that is having proceeded by information.
This was certainly -- this was certainly a notice to the -- the defendant that the Government here did not consider it and it could not be a capital offense.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well I -- if that is to be it, why wouldn't it be just as well, if there's a -- we got a rule generally, just to say that when it doesn't, information should say, should show on its face that it's not capital because would that harm the Government?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Well, when you say “harm” sir --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I mean that the information on its face should show that the man was released unharmed.
What injury would that do to the Government in the practical affair that's enforcing the law?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: From here on in, I should say it would do no more injury than requiring the Government to --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But it is --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: -- allege the greater in an indictment.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Anything back behind except this man's case so far as you know of, it would do the government any injury and the cases that have been tried.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Well, I cannot speak of my own knowledge.
I do not know whether it would do further injury.
I -- I do not know.
I cannot at this moment stand in the point.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You don't know how many cases would be affected by this.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I would say that what would be affected is a long and -- so far as I know, unquestioned line of authority that this Court and the lower courts have held and that is where it is the greater aspect of the offense, you do charge the greater crime.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm not talking about the line of authority.
I'm talking about the practical effect --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- of some kind of rule that if we have the document, if we have to construe it then in connection with the rule.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I cannot now tell you sir because my -- because I am not -- I do not work intimately in this field what the other practical effects of this would be.
I would have to rely on the three strings in my bow.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And the third string amounts to -- the third string amounts to saying that the information must be right because it couldn't be wrong.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: One could -- when you say that the information must be right because it couldn't be wrong is perhaps to state it as its simplest then that makes it the third string to our bow.
I -- I suggest that the other two are far more compelling.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Where in your -- where in your brief do you argue that third -- that third string?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: The filing of the information alone?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, And that manner would -- would prevent a -- a capital verdict.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I will find it for just -- in just a second, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I -- I saw only two.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Well I -- the one that's been -- sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I saw only two issues here.
One of them is that permission to withdraw petitioner's waivers of his procedural rights, his plea of guilty voluntarily and intelligently made was properly refused.
And the second part is that the Court had jurisdiction to proceed by information under the facts of this case.
Now, I'd -- I'd just like to know where your third string is that, namely, that if they did proceed this way, that under no circumstances could be -- he be convicted of a capital offense.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I would say --

Is that one on the page here in the view of this present --

turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: The petitioner could not have been given the death penalty on his plea on this case.
Rule 7 is explicit on the point.
No person charged by information could suffer the death penalty.
The information would not support a sentence more severe than life imprisonment so that the third is mentioned, sir, on 36 of our brief sir.

I would say that the argument with respect to the line of cases starting -- which I've started with Cordel and which deal with -- with the National Prohibition Act for example, the -- the two aspects of an offense or the bank robbery or mail theft do not appear in our brief because these were developed as I was preparing this case for argument and I'm as -- I -- I have developed these points more fully than I normally would only because they do not --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They did not go to different statutes.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And one would have to read the statute to see whether the punishment provision as it were an ingredient of the offense or in the next post statute determination for the Court in sentencing.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I would say that one would but they are sufficiently similar.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You should do that.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: There's no case just like this that we have found.
Now, if I may direct myself for just -- for my remaining time to the due process argument that has been made by my adversary.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: To the what?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I would like to direct my time to the due process (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Oh due process, yes.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: That my adversary referred to.
I really think that this --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't want to interrupt you again but before you get through with that aspect what -- what you call the due process.
I hope you will find time to comment on my view one doesn't have to go to due process to deal with the problem.
If one found in propriety they use that including term in the FBI man seeing the judge in the chambers, ex-party before the judge knew what kind of plea the defendant would make.

That's -- that's part of our supervisory function in dealing with the conduct of lower courts in connection with the rule as the probation officer, one doesn't have to go as far as due process to find impropriety here.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: On the other hand sir, although one may find the impropriety and certainly, the Government does not state that the conduct of the judge in entertaining Mr. Lill in his chambers prior to accepting the plea is one that can be commended.I am not at all sure that the simple impropriety unless it had some effect on the rights of the accused.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How do we know?

How do we know and the whole purport of the federal rule is that he shouldn't be influenced by knowledge about the kind of a federal appeared before him in deciding whether to accept this plea of guilty or not?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Well, sir, I suggest that the -- the per quod of the federal rules have never gone to the point where a judge who has tried a man and has had -- and has imposed sentence, and for one reason or another, has had that sentence in trial reversed by an appellant court, I know of no reason why that judge is ever precluded from retrying the same man yet that is -- isn't that in the same spirit?
Here is a judge who has gotten information about the man's criminal background one thing and another but we had so far as I know, never ruled a judge out of a second --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, but because we have assumed that judges who are reversed by Courts of Appeals are sufficiently disciplined to at least beyond the alert in regard to their conduct where the case is retried.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: That --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And the part which is a very important element from my point of view in considering the conduct of the kind of man who ought to be and presumably normally are under federal courts, our own profession and particular judge's profession train them in that kind of discipline.

But that's a very different thing from a judge having listened to a report that evil conduct and mischievousness but a fellow who then has appearing before him in an independent role in deciding what to do with him.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Well sir, whether it'd be due process or whether it'd be the power of this Court to supervise the administration of the criminal law that is no longer in this case.
Whatever the grounds were, the Court of Appeals saw to it that this man was brought up for sentence by a judge who had not engaged in that practice, Judge Kennamer --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But before you go --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: having died --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- to that Mr. Silverman, don't you have to meet this argument though that Mr. Moore made?

That when you read what it was that was said by the Court of Appeals before the judgment was amended, in effect what was said was, the conviction had a constitutional infirmity in it for the many reasons stated which had the consequence of making it utterly void.

And that the fact was the fact, this discretion of the trial judge to resentance on a -- in respect to a void conviction, it's just something that the Court of Appeals could not have allowed the District Court to do.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: May be sir that you're operating on an erroneous impression, I -- I believe you are all right?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well maybe I am.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: What happened in the first --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: One of the arguments that was said, that's the argument that was said.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: No, I'm -- I'm not sure if that is my opponent's argument.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: But let me just explain what did happen here.
The Court of Appeals did use the language in the first time that it considered the merits after the 2255 hearing before Judge -- before Judge Johnson.
They did use the language that my adversary cited to the Court.
And they concluded their opinion and indeed their mandate originally prepared contained the language.
The judgment is reversed and the cause is remanded with directions to grant the motion to satisfy the conviction and sentence, and to proceed further and not inconsistently herewith.
However, the United States --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Where is that here?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: It is in the reported case which is not in our transcript.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That was page 268 of the record.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter

turn.text: But what case?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: The remand is on --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman

Justice Brennan called my attention to page 268 of the record.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it's in the footnote?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: However it said, immediately the United States turned to move for reargument before rehearing.
And the Court, while it's opinion was fresh in its mind and when it had a chance to see what the implications of this language were, then changed its mandate.

And its mandate then with, that is it added to what appears, the language, instead of putting a period after herewith, they put a comma there and they then went on “including if the District Court is of the opinion that the ends of justice require it, permitting the defendant to withdraw his waiver of counsel and his plea of guilty and to stand trial.”

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now that's the very addition to which Judge Rives addressed himself they're valuing what Judge Rives said.
He said that that was utterly incompetent.
That was for the reason that the Court already knows that this was another void condition.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Now I say --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is that what he said?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: That is what he said but Judge Rives' position in this case is a very interesting one.
In the first place, he said when this first came up, when there was no 2255 here --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And this is issue is before us for a decision.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: What he said was that --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I say this issue is before us for a decision.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: As to whether or not the -- the Court -- what the Court meant by using the language that it did, of course.
And I would say to you that the Court has interpreted what it meant on two separate occasions.

One on the rehearing, when it amended its mandate, and the second time on the appeal from the new sentence when it found specifically that the district George -- judge had meticulously carried out the mandate.

And that appears in the -- in the record on page 267 of the record by suitable language in the opinion itself and by similar precise terms in the mandate, we sought on rehearing to make it plain that the sentence of conviction of 30 years imprisonment was alone mandatorily to be set aside.
And that is to the plea of guilty in waivers the District Court was free to allow such of these as the interest of justice might require.
The District Court finding expressly that the interest of justice did not so require, paid scrupulous heed to and carried out the precise terms of our mandate.

So that the Court of Appeals who knew best what it meant, said that it did not mean that this denial of due process or Justice Frankfurter's lesser formulation of -- of the -- of the problem, it -- it did not say that this vitiated the proceedings at all.
It vitiated the sentence and the sentence was then re-imposed.
The -- the trial judge made very, very specific findings with respect to what have taken place before Judge Kennamer and found that the pleas and the waivers were all quite voluntarily made.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: What is the (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I'm sorry, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: What was (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I would say the conversation between Agent Lill and Judge Kennamer prior to the court appearance.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: And nothing more.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: And nothing more.

I will say in -- in all fairness because the Court does use the language, the incontinent speed and inordinate haste of the proceedings, I would only add -- I -- I would say that at first the Court said that but if we are to find out what it meant, we must look to its mandate and its subsequent opinion.
And secondly, this Court may inspect the transcript of what took place before Judge Kennamer.

And I am thoroughly convinced that this Court will find that the defendant here involved, who when he came before Judge Kennamer was no stranger to the criminal law to use the phrase that the cases used.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I beg your pardon sir?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Well I can -- I can tell you his familiarity with the criminal law because that is a part of this record.
And Judge Johnson elicited the information from this man.
He had been convicted of two prior direct offenses.
He escaped from Chillicothe Institute.
He stole a car.
He then had it on robbery.
He was sentenced for that.
I can go on and on, sir and -- and indicate to you that this man knew very well what it is that he was charged with and what it is that he was doing and that the record is replete.
And if I -- if I may I can -- I can deal with any one of these things and point out where in the record.
This man was informed of his rights to counsel.
This happened time and time again from the moment he came before the Commissioner on arraignment until the -- the time that he was sentenced by the Court.
He was told by the Commissioner, he was told by the FBI agent, he was told by the United States Attorney and his codefendant even protested that, “Don't bother us now, we -- we'd had enough of this.
We don't want counsel.”
And he was told by the judge -- he was told by the judge on several occasions in -- during the course of the hearing.

So that the - the talk about his -- his waiver of counsel I suggest is not substantiated by the record but in fact the record points out that this man knew, had adequate advice with respect to his right to counsel.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Was there any -- was there any showing one way or the other that what Lill said to Judge Kennamer was true or untrue?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Yes, sir there was.
And the --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Yes, sir.
The judge found -- Judge Johnson found that whatever Mr. Lill told Judge Kennamer was not full and that finding was approved by both three Circuit Court Judges.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: No, I don't quite understand why you said that the -- Lill conversation (Inaudible) sentence when under the rule, if complied with, Judge Kennamer could have -- if this conversation had taken place ex parte, after the plea but before a sentence, there would be no violation of the rule.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I would say that the Court of Appeals held that it vitiated the sentence.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, is that --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I do not now try to --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Does that make any sense, I mean what sense does that make?

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: At most, though we're in that posture before this Court, I think that I would be arguing that this was at most a technical violation of the -- of the rule that is that the Judge heard it before rather than after sentence.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, if the rule that was violated and the rule that's entitled to have a sanction irrespective of prejudice and non prejudice, it seems to me the consequence is that this whole thing has to be swept out and -- and start all over again, that -- that it doesn't provide any sanction if the rule is to say we'll wipe out the sentence and leave the plea on the -- standing.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Well, I submit sir that what happened here and what offended perhaps the -- the Circuit Court was the -- not the untruth of whatever Mr. Lill may have told the --the trial -- the trial judge because that was all true.
And Judge Johnson developed it on his own before the resentence that admissions from the defendant.
But that there was something wrong about a man imposing sentence having gained information in -- in a way that the rule did not contemplate.
And that the Court of Appeals felt that if there was any injury to this defendant, the injury was occasioned only in the sentence.
And in the next sets of caution perhaps it said, “We will do away with the injury that may have been caused here.
And we will have this man go back and be resentenced.”
And indeed that is what happened that is -- it was pointed out.
12 years was taken from the sentence.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: The impression that you get from reading the earlier Court of Appeals is taking at least the one that I got.
Was it what outraged him so much was the fact that they thought that Judge Kennamer had rushed this fellow into a plea.
And if you stop with that one opinion of the Court, why -- that's I would have supposes that they would set aside the whole thing.
It's only when you get this surprise move -- the surprise clarification in the rehearing, the Government's petition for rehearing that the -- that the --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: But Justice -- Justice Harlan I would say --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Basis that this -- the basis, the final basis this is left was, seems to me to disappear and to (Inaudible) I don't understand that at all.

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Well I would say that although the Court used that language, what they meant was clear from what they did.
And they could not have meant the literal word that they used.

But whether they had or no, I think that this Court may inspect the transcript and find that -- and I believe will find that what happened before Judge Kennamer at the time of the sentence was not wholly appropriate and proper under the circumstances.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: At the time of the sentence (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: I beg your pardon, at the time of the taking of the plea and sentence --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: -- on a Monday morning.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: That is to plea in the -- the waiver of indictment and the --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: The waiver of indictment, the waiver of counsel, the plea and the sentence.
I'm sure this -- when I say I'm sure I'm over speaking.
I -- I submit to this Court that an inspection of that record will convince this court on its own whatever that the Circuit Court may have done.
But this was all together fair.
And what --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: leon_silverman
turn.label: Mr. Leon Silverman
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) you're wrong, you're not -- I don't want to stop you here you can go right on but I would like to (Inaudible) before you sit down, in what -- in your judgment would be the consequence (Voice Overlap) it should be held that it was an error not permit him to withdraw his plea of guilty.
